Next Tuesday at 3:30 p.m.in
Shriver Hall, Steven Muller will
officially become the tenth
president of the Johns Hopkins
University. The installation, a
small "family affair," will be held
in conjunction with
commemoration activities
celebrating the 96th anniversary of
the University's founding in
1876. A reception will follow in
the Hutzler Reading Room of
Gilman Hall.
Over 100 faculty members
from all the divisions of the
University will march in an
academic procession led by the
Chief Marshal Dr. A. Edward
Maumenee, Professor of
Ophthalmology at the Hopkins
Medical School.
Speakers at the ceremony will
be limited to members of the
Hopkins community. Welcoming
remarks will be given by Robert
D. H. Harvey, chairman of the

presentation of an honorary

Reid, professor emeritus of
Chemistry, and music by the
Hopkins Glee Club and a brass
choir from the Peabody Institute.

one of several rituals involved in
the installation ceremony. The
Chief Marshal will carry the
traditional mace to the podium

the ceremony. He will be

B-ballers' win streak
ended by Loyola
By BILL SCHOEFFLER
Loyola College survived a surprisingly
strong showing by the visiting Blue Jays
last night, winning the ninth of their last
ten games 79-70. Most people expected
Loyola to have little trouble with the
scrappy young Hopkins team, but
someone forgot to tell Rupert's boys,
who were out to extend their three game
winning streak.
Quickly overcoming a slow start, the
Blue Jays grabbed the lead early in the
game as center Bill Jews dominated the
defensive boards. Hopkins staved off a
Greyhound surge that saw Loyola take a
short-lived 29-28 lead, when the Blue
Jays, led by sophomore guards Bobby
Freedman and John Rutter, charged right
back to carry a 37-32 advantage into the
locker room at halftime.
Having shot a remarkable 67% from
the floor, hitting on 14 of 21 shots in the
first half, the Blue Jays were ready to go
all out in the second half. They widened
the gap to ten points as Rupert's varying
zone defense had the Greyhounds
stymied. The game could easily have
turned into a runaway at this point, were

it not for nine key turnovers that kept
Hopkins from putting points on the
scoreboard. According to Coach Rupert,
"turnovers have been bugging us all year,
but we are handling the ball much better
now than we were earlier in the season."
With thirteen minutes left to play,
Loyola finally settled down and began to
make their shots count. Sparked by the
alert play of Gene Gwiazdowski and the
suddenly unerring shooting of Ed Butler,
who scored 16 of his game high 21 points
in the second half comeback, Loyola
took command of the game. Outscoring
the Blue Jays 17-5 over a five minute
period, the Greyhounds picked up the
momentum that carried them to eventual
victory. As Rupert acknowledged after
the game,"they just wore us out," but he
had every reason to be proud of the Blue
Jays' overall effort.
Playing another solid game for the
losers was senior Gary Handleman, who
contributed sixteen points to the effort,
and bench star Glen Rasin almost got the
team fired up again with three successive
long jumpers that forestalled a collapse in
the face of Loyola's final flourish.

By SUE WOOLHISER
The current Children's Art
Exhibit at the Baltimore Museum
of Art is an exciting rival to any
of the museum's more
conventional exhibits. The
spontaneous vitality and natural
freedom of expression of the
works puts them in favorable
contrast to the more
self-conscious products of
professional artists.
The exhibit was arranged by
Mrs. Albright of the Art Division
of City Schools in response to
the extremely successful exhibit
of children's art held this
summer. The present exhibit
features the art of students from

grades kindergarten to twelve,
done during the fall semester of
this year.
Every public school in
Baltimore with art instruction is
represented by at least one work.
These works were submitted by
the art teachers of each school
and chosen for artistic value as
well as for variety.
Invigorating
The younger children's works,
showing invigorating primitive
form and colors, are a
sentimental favorite. This section
of the exhibit resembles a
collection of the best refrigerator
doors and bulletin boares in
Baltimore. Different topics—city

life, animals, people, sports—lead
to paintings entitled "I'd Like a
Giraffe Because He's So Tall" or
"My Mother's a Crossing Guard."
There's a kitten as big as a house,
"A Very Hot Day" with an
orange tempra sky, a Christ with
a rainboy halo and many other
charmingly unconventional
interpretations.
The experiments in different
media are an interesting part of
the works of the older students.
Wire or plaster sculpture,
mosaics, silk-screened prints,
weavings, and reliefs are included
along with water colors and oils,
and one purple paper mache
elephant. This variation in media

stresses the individuality of each
piece as the older students
demonstrate artistic talent
beyond a childish view.
Highlighting the student works
are the photographs of Dick
Holden, the Baltimore school
photographer. These photographs
are an integral part of the exhibit
itself; showing the students at
work and presenting contrasts
between the actual topics the
younger children were given and
way in which they were
interpreted. Holden's work,
however, is valuable in itself as
fine photography and is an
excellent extra touch to an
interesting exhibit.

Albright suggested that, in
addition to recognizing the
children's art work, the exhibit
has demonstrated the success of
the museum's tours. These tours
handle between 700 and 800
children every week,
concentrating on a particular
topic such as color or animals.
Most of the children whosw
works have been exhibited have
been on these tours and the
school's art department has
noted the significant effect of
this exposure on the children's
works The exhibit is on display
in the Sadie A. May Young
People's Art Center until
February 27th.

B-ballers' win streak
ended by Loyola
By BILL SCHOEFFLER
Loyola College survived a surprisingly
strong showing by the visiting Blue Jays
last night, winning the ninth of their last
ten games 79-70. Most people expected
Loyola to have little trouble with the
scrappy young Hopkins team, but
someone forgot to tell Rupert's boys,
who were out to extend their three game
winning streak.
Quickly overcoming a slow start, the
Blue Jays grabbed the lead early in the
game as center Bill Jews dominated the
defensive boards. Hopkins staved off a
Greyhound surge that saw Loyola take a
short-lived 29-28 lead, when the Blue
Jays, led by sophomore guards Bobby
Freedman and John Rutter, charged right
back to carry a 37-32 advantage into the
locker room at halftime.
Having shot a remarkable 67% from
the floor, hitting on 14 of 21 shots in the
first half, the Blue Jays were ready to go
all out in the second half. They widened
the gap to ten points as Rupert's varying
zone defense had the Greyhounds
stymied. The game could easily have
turned into a runaway at this point, were

it not for nine key turnovers that kept
Hopkins from putting points on the
scoreboard. According to Coach Rupert,
"turnovers have been bugging us all year,
but we are handling the ball much better
now than we were earlier in the season."
With thirteen minutes left to play,
Loyola finally settled down and began to
make their shots count. Sparked by the
alert play of Gene Gwiazdowski and the
suddenly unerring shooting of Ed Butler,
who scored 16 of his game high 21 points
in the second half comeback, Loyola
took command of the game. Outscoring
the Blue Jays 17-5 over a five minute
period, the Greyhounds picked up the
momentum that carried them to eventual
victory. As Rupert acknowledged after
the game,"they just wore us out," but he
had every reason to be proud of the Blue
Jays' overall effort.
Playing another solid game for the
losers was senior Gary Handleman, who
contributed sixteen points to the effort,
and bench star Glen Rasin almost got the
team fired up again with three successive
long jumpers that forestalled a collapse in
the face of Loyola's final flourish.

Children's art exhibit at the museum invigorating
By SUE WOOLHISER
The current Children's Art
Exhibit at the Baltimore Museum
of Art is an exciting rival to any
of the museum's more
conventional exhibits. The
spontaneous vitality and natural
freedom of expression of the
works puts them in favorable
contrast to the more
self-conscious products of
professional artists.
The exhibit was arranged by
Mrs. Albright of the Art Division
of City Schools in response to
the extremely successful exhibit
of children's art held this
summer. The present exhibit
features the art of students from

grades kindergarten to twelve,
done during the fall semester of
this year.
Every public school in
Baltimore with art instruction is
represented by at least one work.
These works were submitted by
the art teachers of each school
and chosen for artistic value as
well as for variety.
Invigorating
The younger children's works,
showing invigorating primitive
form and colors, are a
sentimental favorite. This section
of the exhibit resembles a
collection of the best refrigerator
doors and bulletin boares in
Baltimore. Different topics—city

life, animals, people, sports—lead
to paintings entitled "I'd Like a
Giraffe Because He's So Tall" or
"My Mother's a Crossing Guard."
There's a kitten as big as a house,
"A Very Hot Day" with an
orange tempra sky, a Christ with
a rainboy halo and many other
charmingly unconventional
interpretations.
The experiments in different
media are an interesting part of
the works of the older students.
Wire or plaster sculpture,
mosaics, silk-screened prints,
weavings, and reliefs are included
along with water colors and oils,
and one purple paper mache
elephant. This variation in media

stresses the individuality of each
piece as the older students
demonstrate artistic talent
beyond a childish view.
Highlighting the student works
are the photographs of Dick
Holden, the Baltimore school
photographer. These photographs
are an integral part of the exhibit
itself; showing the students at
work and presenting contrasts
between the actual topics the
younger children were given and
way in which they were
interpreted. Holden's work,
however, is valuable in itself as
fine photography and is an
excellent extra touch to an
interesting exhibit.

Albright suggested that, in
addition to recognizing the
children's art work, the exhibit
has demonstrated the success of
the museum's tours. These tours
handle between 700 and 800
children every week,
concentrating on a particular
topic such as color or animals.
Most of the children whosw
works have been exhibited have
been on these tours and the
school's art department has
noted the significant effect of
this exposure on the children's
works The exhibit is on display
in the Sadie A. May Young
People's Art Center until
February 27th.
